Erik Wilde (@dret): What Would the Web Do?
Approaching API Design with a Webby Mindset

(2) Summary

APIs are very popular nowadays and very likely will only become more popular in the future. After all, they are the glue that hold digital building blocks together, and digitalization isn't going anywhere anytime soon. But this also means that APIs will become more ubiquitous, that there will be more APIs to manage within and across organizations, and the API space will become more dynamic and more diverse. As a result, API landscapes may start to resemble the Web in terms of scale, diversity, and complexity. It thus may be a good approach to think about what the solution to a given API problem looks like in the Web space. In this presentation, we look at a variety of topics from this perspective and we learn to approach API problems with a webby mindset. Don't hold yourself back by thinking that "APIs are different", instead start thinking "What Would the Web Do?"

(8) Decentralized Ecosystems



From Systems to Ecosystems Erik Wilde (@dret): What Would the Web Do?
Approaching API Design with a Webby Mindset

(9) Optimizing for Resilience and Change

  • Integrated Systems are not going anywhere anytime soon
    • Integration allows optimizations that outperform more loosely coupled solutions
    • Integration can also be the result of Conway's Law [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conway%27s_law] in action
  • Today's need for speed requires us to better separate architectural layers
    • Components/Capabilities are designed and implemented as usual
    • Composing these components is fundamentally different from building them
  • APIs are connective tissue and implementation encapsulation for components
    • Everything that is being built must be self-contained and have an API (microservices)
    • Everything that is being used must be used through its API (API first)

(11) Microservices Architecture: Using APIs to do the Right Thing [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DBoNlKoGVG4]



Microservices Erik Wilde (@dret): What Would the Web Do?
Approaching API Design with a Webby Mindset

(12) The SOA Crisis

  • SOAP-style SOA are traditional IT monoliths exposing some capabilities
  • MSA #1 goal is to create a loosely coupled service landscape
    • Shared data storage creates coupling
    • Shared infrastructure creates coupling
    • Shared libraries create coupling
  • Using APIs is one of the few overlaps between SOAP-style SOA and MSA


Microservices Erik Wilde (@dret): What Would the Web Do?
Approaching API Design with a Webby Mindset

(13) Microservices are SOA!



Microservices Erik Wilde (@dret): What Would the Web Do?
Approaching API Design with a Webby Mindset

(14) Microservices are SOA done Right!

  • Decouple implementations and not just interfaces
  • Velocity is determined by how hard it is to make changes
  • The biggest problem is not access to capabilities but capability agility
  • Microservices apply Web architecture to Enterprise IT
    • Implementation details are completely invisible to service users
    • Service consumption only uses well-defined and uniform interfaces

(16) Why API Standards Matter and How to Use Them [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WAAd9Z84zaQ]



Standards Erik Wilde (@dret): What Would the Web Do?
Approaching API Design with a Webby Mindset

(17) 1. Patterns

  • The same design questions have to be addressed in many APIs
  • It becomes apparent that these are necessary but not sufficient
    • They are necessary because these issues need to be addressed
    • They are not sufficient because it's not how value is created


Standards Erik Wilde (@dret): What Would the Web Do?
Approaching API Design with a Webby Mindset

(18) 2. Personal Standards

  • Addressing patterns [1. Patterns (1)] more effectively by reusing design elements
  • Helps with surfacing we all seem to address the same issue realizations
  • Increases personal efficiency but is ineffective for the organization


Standards Erik Wilde (@dret): What Would the Web Do?
Approaching API Design with a Webby Mindset

(19) 3. Organizational Standards

  • Creating consistency across organizational APIs
    • Less effort for API designers (focus on core design questions)
    • Less effort for API consumers (coherence across the API landscape)
  • API Design Guidelines [https://dret.github.io/guidelines/] are a well-known pattern
    • Guidelines should be participatory and constantly evolving


Standards Erik Wilde (@dret): What Would the Web Do?
Approaching API Design with a Webby Mindset

(20) 4. Vertical Standards

  • Domain-specific standards may emerge
    • Many of these are monolithic and have interoperability in mind
    • Focusing more on building blocks could make efforts more effective
  • Most often driven by consortia and their member organizations


Standards Erik Wilde (@dret): What Would the Web Do?
Approaching API Design with a Webby Mindset

(21) 5. Global Standards

  • Global standards body for cross-domain building blocks
  • High threshold and potentially time-consuming process
  • Best chance for tooling and other standards to evolve
    • Stable building blocks provide the best foundation

(23) Hypermedia APIs [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zwuoYgLgDUM]



Hypermedia Erik Wilde (@dret): What Would the Web Do?
Approaching API Design with a Webby Mindset

(24) Hypermedia and Workflows

  • Hypermedia combines state representation and possible further interactions
    • Resource state allows clients to understand the current content
    • Links allow clients to learn about the possible next steps
    • Clients select and follow a link based on their application goals
  • Workflows are represented by providing navigation options (affordances)
    • Making it easier for clients to be driven by available options
    • Seamless fabric of navigation across individual APIs


Hypermedia Erik Wilde (@dret): What Would the Web Do?
Approaching API Design with a Webby Mindset

(25) Hypermedia and API Evolution

  • Extensibility generally is a good idea for APIs
    • Eliminates or reduces the need to do potentially expensive versioning
  • Hypermedia representations by definition combine data and control elements
    • Data extensibility results in the usual benefits of allowing representations to evolve
    • Control extensibility results in the ability to add new workflow paths
  • Hypermedia-based evolution has many patterns to choose from
    • Incremental additions can show up as new links in extension slots
    • Complete new APIs can be advertised as new start resources in home documents

(27) API Versioning [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IUWM-LOwE3g]



Versioning Erik Wilde (@dret): What Would the Web Do?
Approaching API Design with a Webby Mindset

(28) Meaningful Core Semantics

  • The core of the API allows clients to have meaningful interactions
    • The starting point of an API should be meaningful and complete
  • The core of the API is robust over time
    • Anything that is added to the core does not change the core semantics
  • Anything that is not part of the core can be safely ignored
    • mustIgnore semantics allow safe interactions beyond closely coordinated groups


Versioning Erik Wilde (@dret): What Would the Web Do?
Approaching API Design with a Webby Mindset

(29) Well-Defined Extension Points

  • APIs should be clear about where extensions are allowed
    • API metamodels often decide where (potential) extension points are
    • API schemas/definitions should further narrow down where extensions are allowed
  • API tests can make sure that the extension points are properly implemented
    • Extensions in allowed places are ignored and tests should succeed
    • Extensions in other places should raise errors about malformed content


Versioning Erik Wilde (@dret): What Would the Web Do?
Approaching API Design with a Webby Mindset

(30) Well-Defined Processing Model

  • Extensions are well-defined and their handling is well-defined as well
    • Extension points [Well-Defined Extension Points (1)] make it clear where to expect extensions
    • Processing models make it clear what to do with extensions
  • mustIgnore is a popular and good choice for extension processing
    • Some formats allow extensions to declare their processing model (such as mustUnderstand)
    • HTML has a rule of ignoring unknown elements but processing their content
  • How to learn about extensions is a different matter

Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): What Would the Web Do?
Approaching API Design with a Webby Mindset

(33) Linear Business



Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): What Would the Web Do?
Approaching API Design with a Webby Mindset

(34) Platform: A Definition [https://www.modernmonopolies.com/]

  • What a platform is:
    • Generating value by facilitating exchanges/interactions between groups
    • Creating networks of users and resources that can be accessed on-demand
    • Using the network effect to grow communities and markets
    • Creating value by reducing transaction costs and/or by externalizing innovation
  • What a platform is not:
    • It is not just technology, it is the business model enabled by technology
    • It is not a linear business model with unidirectional value chains
    • It is not (completely) owning the means of production


Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): What Would the Web Do?
Approaching API Design with a Webby Mindset

(35) The Platform Money Press



Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): What Would the Web Do?
Approaching API Design with a Webby Mindset

(36) Tech & Biz = Platform

  • Platforms enable organizations to create and deliver value
  • Technology can be both limiting and enabling
    • Limiting when creation/delivery seems to be too slow/costly
    • Enabling when digitalization opens new opportunities
  • Business can be both limiting and enabling
    • Limiting when business demands are not aligned with technology
    • Enabling when technology is used to create/deliver value faster
  • Any platform must make sure to align technology and business


Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): What Would the Web Do?
Approaching API Design with a Webby Mindset

(37) Platforming: Co-Creation is Key

Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): What Would the Web Do?
Approaching API Design with a Webby Mindset

(41) What Would the Web do?

  • Designing for change and resilience still is a path we are all on
  • Not every problem is Web scale or needs to solve problems the Web way
  • There likely are useful patterns or at least some inspiration on the Web


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): What Would the Web Do?
Approaching API Design with a Webby Mindset
